sp.p: I tell thee Madge, I saw it with my owne eyes, and thought the next time the Mountebank came I'de buy some on't to see what mettle our Frank the Faulkner was made on.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Why sirrah, he loves thee well enough without it: Would I know who lov'd me halfe so well.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Yes verily, I confesse I think he loves me dearly well, but yet not so dearly as I'de have him. He's such a maydenly man!—

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Why? I'm sure I saw him kisse thee twenty times together, to be sure so often that my teeth water'd soundly.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Twenty times? what's twenty times? what's that? 'Tis done before one can say What's this? Twenty times? Tis a mighty piece of businesse. And then forsooth, he must stroak his Hawke, And then forsooth he must feed his Hawke, and then forsooth, he must bathe his Hawke, And then forsooth, he must lie down by his Hawke, and see his Hawke pick her self, and prune her self, and there's such a deal of fidling, and such a deal of fadling, And then forsooth, he must goe abroad a hawking, and stay out all day, and then at night come home as weary as his dogs, and sit without life or soul, That one has as much comfort in him as comes to nothing.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Well Cis, wou'd some body did but love me halfe so well, a that condition it cost me a fall.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Goodly, goodly, wou'd Antony at George were here to draw his name out a your politique mouth, You are so close, and so wise now.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Why, I am not ashamed to name him, nor he of his name: Well, he has cost me many a bitter sigh in his dayes, Yet I dare take my oath hee's as honest a young man as lives by bread.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Why dost thou sigh? He may leave his honesty when he will, and see ne'r a whit the worse for't.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: I care not, so he left it with no body but me; yet in the way of honesty too (I tell ye but so:) Well, no body knowes what I have endur'd for his sake; But I may thank my modesty for't, and my Mother for that. She gave my a Rule forsooth, once, which I ha' beshrew'd her for a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: What Rule was that, Madge?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p:
She charg'd me, that when any sued for my love, I should be coy, and say Noforsooth, and still Noforsooth,
and Noforsooth, which I ha'done so long, that I have almost Noforsooth'd away all my fortunes. But sirrah, (here's none but Thee and I) Ile tell thee. This very day two moneths (well fare all good tokens) Antony at the George would needs ha'me downe into his Wine-celler, and gave me a Pint of Brown-bastard; and being in a good humour, brake his minde to me, And taking a glasse of Wine, wisht it might be his poyson if he did not love me with all his heart.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: But did he drink it?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Every drop as I live; Nay more, wou'd may nere store, if he offered not (Ile tell it to thee) to fetch a Licence instantly, and marry me forthwith, if I'de goe with him; But I, like a puppinos'd foole, followed my Mothers directions, and cry'd Noforsooth, to make him the more eager, which he taking in earnest, flung away in a pet, and as I live, took me at my word, and never spake kindly to me since: And this is the fruits of Noforsooth.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: And wert thou not serv'd in thy kind, to be such an asse, to refuse a good thing when 'twas offer'd?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Nay, Sirrah, See the luck on't; Had he but ask'd me once more, I had resolv'd to ha'taken him at his word: But if he, or any other hereafter take Madge a crying Noforsooth, I'le give him leave to bite off my tongue, and spit it in my face, I tell ye but so.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Dost thou think he has forsaken thee upon't?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p:
I can't tell: I ha'made many a frivolous errand to the George since, And when he sees me, the Gentleman will bite his lip, and put off his hat, but as I live, neither kisse me, nor nothing else, That I came away with a flea in mine eare, and in a fustian Fret, and
had such Qualmes, and such Swamps come over my stomach all night long—

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: But art not mightily troubled with him in thy dreames?

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: O, sirrah, abomination; There's ne'r a night scapes me, on my conscience: Sometimes, methinks I see him twirling up his pretty little black beard: sometimes stroaking up his fore-top: sometimes singing that heavenly tune of Walsingham to his Citterne: sometimes crying Anon Anon Sir, and running up stairs: sometimes Very welcome Gentlemen, Is all paid i'th'Rose? which he fetches up with such a grace—As indeed every thing he does becomes him most sweetly. O how I could curse this peevish tongue of mine for saying that last Noforsooth. Ah! if he had askt me the Question but once more, verly I had been to morrow two moneths gone: But who can help it?

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Well Madge, our conditions are much alike: we must even comfort one another as well as we can.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: That's but cold comfort Cis: I but my case is thousand times worse then thine; Thou mayst see him thou lovest every day, and dine together, and sup together, and sleepe together under the same roofe; but I a poore forsaken creature must waste my disconsolate hours in thinking, & in sighing, and in [Weeps] sobbing. Insomuch that I han't eaten a bit of bread that has done me any good these three dayes. But yet I can't choose but laugh to think —Ha, ha, ha, ha, how Frank the Fawlkner —Ha, ha, ha, ha, was catch'd in's Roguery last night, Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: How? Prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: I think my heart will burst when I think on't. Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Prithee tell me the conceit.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Sirrah, yesternight when thou wert gone up with my Lady, Frank and I were raking Husbands and Wives in the Embers, And Frank hearing the stayres creake, and thinking thee hadst been comming downe, catcht my Lady fast by the —Ha, ha, ha, ha, middle; but she lent him such a whirrit upon the eare, that all the house rung on't: But 'twould make a Horse break his Halter to see how like an Asse poore Frank lookt and sneakt away with his taile clapt betweene his legs, Ha, ha, ha, ha, Did he not tell thee on't yet?

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: No verily, I see him not to day: Huds lifelykins, Alas poore heart, But 'tis no matter: Let him keep home adayes then, that he may see what he does, and whom he embraces. But sirrah, now I think on't, I ha some a Dolls pouder, which I stole from her, Till we get more, let's try conclusions with that.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: With all my heart, let's: But how shall we give it them?

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: How? Leave that to me: Frank and I will goe to the George, and drink a pint with Antony, and then we'll send for thee, And I warrant thee Ile spice their Cups, and then
sp.l: In spight of my mother, my grandame, my aunt,
We'll drink off our cups, and make a night on't.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: A match! Come, let's way; we shall be both hang'd for staying so long.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.p: Artesio, Can you resolve us yet concerning the death of Pertenax?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Sir, he was open'd, and we apparently find that he was poyson'd.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.p: Goe Artesio, and comfort thy poore afflicted daughter, Let her know, that we are partners in her forrow, and will be a husband to the widow, and take her welfare into our protection.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Heaven blesse your Highnesse.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.p: Does there appeare any new light by your Examination?

sp.speaker: Formid.
sp.p: Sir, I find there was such a Letter counterfeited from your Highnesse, and a silver Cup was delivered to Kettreena by a stranger, who after the delivery instantly departed. Likewise I find that Pertenax comming in the nick, snatcht it from Kettreena's unwilling hand, and in a passion retyr'd into a roome, not suffering her to follow him, where he was found dead an houre after.

div.p: Another Examinate faith, that he sent for a dramme of Arsnick the night before, but for what purpose the Examinate knoweth not.

Another Examinate, being one of his fervants, saith, that she harkning at the doore, did heare him say, that he would put in a dose of Arsnick into the Cup for? Kettreena, which she saw him search in his pockets for; but being suddenly call'd away by her Lady, stayed not to see the rest. And indeed it is generally beleeved, that he was chiefe Agent in his owne death.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.p: Comodus, what account can you give us of this businesse?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p:
Sir, we found in his pocket the Cup and the Letter, but no Arsnick: Upon suspition I examined Madam Lactusia, and one Cornelius Quack, once servant to Artesio, who falter something in their examination, but deny any knowledge of the proceedings: Onely they both heare that Pertenax counterfeited the Letter, to
see with what Affection his Lady would receive it.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.p: Even like enough, The just reward of a jealous braine.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: But this she added, That when time should serve, she would discover a secret of another nature, which will make such an alteration in the State, as Time could not example: whereupon I committed them both to Prison till a farther Examination.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.p: 'Twas wisely done.

sp.speaker: Formidon,
sp.p: See a firme Conveyance made of all Pertenax his Estate to our use, which we freely give to Kettreena. And you Comodus, take a speciall care to call in her debts that are upon Book and Specialties.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. I.

sp.speaker: Glisterpipe.
sp.p: THe Devill a bit of meat have I gotten these nine dayes, but once a leane scrag end of a Neck of Mutton, which one of my Masters Patients loath'd to eate: Else my whole diet hath been nothing but the overplus of thin Physick-broth, and my drink, the heartlesse reversion of dis-curded Posset-Ale: Insomuch, I had rather be my Masters Hang-man, then his Serving-man; For then perchance I might get a Caft Suit, and a gratuity for a quick dispatch. Knocks at doore. Who's at doore there?

div.stage: Opens it, and enter Page with an Vrinall.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, Is Master Doctor within? I have brought him a Urine.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: From my Lady Albion.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: My Master is very busie, and cannot be spoken with these two houres.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Good Sir, my businesse is upon life and death: I pray bring me to him, and I shall be very thankfull.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: How shall that appeare?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: By this small carnest of a greater Reward.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Wel Sir, I shal make a tryal. Opens the curtain. Sir, here is one would speak with you from my Lady Albion.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Bring him in. Now friend, what's your businesse?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady hath sent you her Urine, and desires your Advice.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Glisterpipe.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Goe ayre it.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Now Ide as liefe he had bid me gone to supper, but take him in that fault, & hang him. Stumbles, & spils the urine, and rises. So, now am I as sure of a crackt Crowne, as my Master is of a whole Angel: But Ile serve him a trick, and save my selfe some labour. Ile make it up againe out of my owne stock.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Has your Lady made no use of any other Doctor formerly?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes Sir, she took advice of a Scottish Doctor, but she is not much the better for him: He drew a great deale of money from her Ladiship, who is now faine to give him money to be rid on him—Whisper.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Tis all but Pisse, and tis not the first time my Master has had an eye to my water.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Truly I cannot tel Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: This water shews no great defect in her Ladiships stomach.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: His Doctorship may sweare it.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Her Ladiship accustomes her self to too thin a diet, eats too much broth, and too many Sillibubs.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Posset-Ale ye meane Sir, a halter stretch ye.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: And does not encourage her stomach with good substantiall meat.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Thanks to your miserable purse Sir, he would if he could get it.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Her Ladiships body is much out of order, and there's a Malignant Hypocondriacall Flate within her, which fumes up, and disturbs her Head: Is she not much troubled with the Head-ache?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes Sir, exceedingly: She complains of it every day.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: She is likewise much troubled with inflamations, and obstructions in the liver, which causes an inordinate swimming in the Braine, and giddinesse. Is she not apt now and then to speak idly?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: O Sir, when the Fit takes her, she speaks never a word of sense: she talks of nothing but Bishops, and Petitions, and I can't tell what, and her tongue runs so wildly, and indeed I think she is scarce sensible sometimes of her own sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: That proceeds altogether from the rude confluence of loose humors. I find by her water, she is much troubled with wind and choller, which occasions a great and frequent heart-burning: Is she not much subject to unaccustomed sadnesse at times?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Extreamly Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I find she has a great imbeeility in her spirits naturall, which causes in her a generall faintnesse, and now and then enclined to the Cardiaca Passio. Is she not often possest with sudden frights, and feares, and jealousies, and mis-understandings?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Exceedingly Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I find likewise, that she is much troubled with the Spleene, which occasions stupidity, melancholy, and at times distractions? Is she not often in a brown study?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Very much Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Well, I feare we must be forc'd to draw some blood from her, which as the case stands now with her, I should be loth to doe. There is some bad blood in her veynes; but if a veyne be once opened, the best blood in her body may chance to passe too, which she can hardly spare, without palpable danger. Untill I see her, I can prescribe little. To morrow I shall wait upon her Ladiship, and what I shall then find fitting, shall be carefully administred. In the meane while, let her keep her head warme, and be very careful of her Temples: Let her forbeare Salt and Usquebagh: Let her use Moderation in her Exercises, wherein she might not be forc'd to lift her armes too neare her head: And for the relieving of her drooping spirits let her recreate her selfe now and then with a game at Irish: Ler her forbeare Noddy, and Chesse, as Games too serious. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Take this, Glisterpipe, to drink my Ladies health.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.l: How odoriserous is a very stoole! how sweet,
When full-cramm'd Purses, and craz'd Bodies meet!
What? more Fees yet? Who's at doore?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Pray is Mr. Doctor within?Ent. Page with an Urinall. I have brought him a water.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: From my Lady Temple.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: He cannot be spoken with as yet, unlesse—

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I know your mind, Sir, let this quicken you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Glisterpipe?

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: One that would speak with your Honour from my Lady Temple.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Bring him in: Now friend, what's your businesse?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady desires your Advice upon her Urine.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Glisterpipe, goe chafe it.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: So, there's a shilling more for Glisterpipe.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: How long has your Lady been sick?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: These three years, Sir: she took a tedious journey to Canterbury, where she conceives she took a surfet with too much Duck, which hath laine very heavy upon her Ladiships stomach ever since.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: This water shewes a great diftemper in her principall Parts, which indeed sets her whole Frame out of Order. Has she taken no Advice formerly?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, she has had many Advisers, but men of mean quality, and of no skill at all.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What were they?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Her poore Neighbours Sir, Coblers, Weavers, Felt-makers, Coachmen, and Brewers Clerks, who pretend a great deale of slovenly skill.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: In good time! But what Doctors had she?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Some Doctors of very good worth, but this Rabble jeers them, and laughs them out of doors.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I find by her Water she has a foule Liver, & can digest no wholsome food: And her first digestion being bad, makes her second worse: Is she not apt to frights?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, her Ladiships stomach was prittily well purg'd of her Canterbury Duck, and being finely at ease, and laid to rest, a rude company of cock-brain'd Rascals in an humor beset her house, and brake downe all her Glasse-windowes, and put her into such a fright, that she has been the worse for't ever since.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I find by her water, there has been too sudden Alterations in her constitution: Is she not sometimes very hot, and sometimes very cold?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes Sir, sometimes as cold as Charity, sometimes as hot as Zeale.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I find obnoxious fumes rising from her stomach, and stupifying her braine: Is she not at times very drowzie?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes Sir, Insomuch that the common people think she is troubled with a Liturgic.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: A Lethargie you meane. It is a Chronicall disease, and time must cure it. But let her know, that so long as she entertaines this rude Rabble of unsanctified Mechanicks, She can never prosper in her health. Till she banish them, there will be no roome for me. Fare ye well.
But heare ye. Let her Fasting be frequent, and her Prayers, Common.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: Sir, I shall pray for your Ladies health.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Fast too.

sp.speaker: Glist.
sp.p: A faire Reward! Tis Supper time: Ile hence. My Pater Nosters shall be like her Pence.

div.stage: Evaldus, Augusta, Bellarm. Pallad: Museus, Artes. Form. Comod. Kettreena, Marina, Roscia, Phonilla, Tripit.
All bow to the Oracle and take their places.
Enter three Pythian Virgin Priests with Censers in their hands, in Linnen Robes, and crown'd with Bayes.

sp.l: 1. Great Apollo, we adore thee.
2. We importune, we implore thee.
2. Thus we prostrate fall before thee.
1. Sacred Phebus draw thee nigher.
2. Grant the boone that we desire.
3. And resent our. holy Fire.
1. Thou before whose open eye
2. All unshadow'd secrets lye,
3. Cleare our doubts, and make reply.

div.stage: Bowe, and stepping nearer to the Oracle, bowe againe, and retiring back, bow the 3. time.

sp.l: 1. When Evaldus shall lay downe,
Shall Bellarmo weare the Crowne?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Apollo lyes: This is the Oracle I appeale to.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: On paine of death, keep silence there. Proceed.
2. When Evaldus shall lay downe,
Shall Palladius were the Crowne?

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Nay now Apollo's ignorant or unjust.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: Silence once more. The next disturberdies. Proceed.
3. When Evaldus shall lay downe,
Shall Museus weare the Crowne?
1 When Evaldus shall lay downe,
2 3 Whose head then shall weare the Crowne?

sp.speaker: Oracle.
sp.l: The Babe unborne shall end the strife,
Whose Mother is both Widow, Maid, and Wife.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: The Oracle speaks Treason, and Apollo's Priests
Are all Impostors—

div.stage: A flash of fire from the Oracle; A cloud of smoak; which being vanisht, Augusta is found dead in her Chaire of State, her Crown struck off, convey'd upon Kettreena's head: Bellarmo, Palladius, and Trippit, dead upon the ground, and the 3. Pythians kneeling upon the floore.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Are we all safe? Are we not all consum'd?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Bellarmo's stricken dead.

sp.speaker: Kett.
sp.l: He's in a trance, O chafe his Temples!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Ye stand too close, Beare back, & give him aire.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Palladius.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Bend him, O bend him forwards.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: He's past recovery.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I feele no Pulse.

sp.speaker: Pho.
sp.l: Her eyes are open.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Methinks I feele some breath.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Stand by.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Are they all dead Artesio?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: All three as dead as earth.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: O unexampled Justice! Who can stand
Before the power of great Apollo's hand?
Augusta, let's away; Our flight may scape
Approaching after-claps: Augusta, come.
What, fall'n asleep?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: The Queene is in a Trance.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Augusta.

sp.speaker: Ket.
sp.l: Heaven blesse the Queene.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She stirs not.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: She breathes not.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Make roome, Stand farther off.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: O she is dead, Is any hope of life?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Sir none at all.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Augusta, deare Augusta, speak,
Move but a finger: O she's past all cure!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But where's her Crowne?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Look here, upon Kettreena's head.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: How came it thither?

sp.speaker: Kett.
sp.l: Most Royall Sir, How this Crown came here
I cannot tell: Excuse me gracious Prince,
Who humbly lay it at your sacred feet.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Kettreena, keep it for us; keep it safe,
Till we require it, and dispose thereof.
Apollo's will must be, who give us patience
To beare his punishments: Take up the dead,
And let us see them all bestow'd, and laid
In the sad Clofets of eternall rest.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Wou'd may never sweare if I had not rather ferve the great Turk in his Gallies, then a Court Lady in her humors.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sirrah, how the poore wenches trembled when we made them stay tother pint. But is my Lady so strict Frank?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
O she's a pestilent vixen when she's angry, and as proud as Lucifer. She has been to me knowledge a whole houre by the Houre-glasse making Faces in a Looking-glasse. Sometimes putting out the nether lippe, sometimes bridling in the chinne; sometimes forming of a smile, sometimes figging up her cheeks, sometimes kissing of her white hand, sometimes
practising a new French Curtsie. And then Cis must be call'd, and then her Ladiships haire must be crispt, and then her Ladiships face must be complexion'd, and then her Ladiships teeth must be scaled, and then her Ladiships browes must be mullited, and then her Ladiships Turkie-egge must be eaten with a good grace. And then her Ladiships foysting dog must be comb'd, and then Cis must be sent for this dressing, and for that petticote, and Madge must be imploy'd for that plaine Hankercher, and then for that purl'd Gorget which Cis was filling all last night. Then fault must be found, then Cis must be chidden, and Madge must be rated: And her sullen Ladiship must keep her chamber all day, and at night her peevish Ladiship must be sick and goe to rest. Then at Midnight Cis must be call'd to kil the Flea that keeps her Ladiship from sleeping forsooth. Then Cis must slip on her petticote to see if the Hall-doore be shut, then downe againe to rate the dogs, then downe againe to fetch her Ladiship some Beere. Then Cis must look under the Bed; after that into the Closer, to see if there be ne'r a Cat to break her Ladiships Glasses. Insomuch that I hold it the greatest misery i'th' world, next being a Lady, to be a Chambermaid. But I must away. Tony, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay Frank, we'll have one sresh pint to drink Madge and Cis's Healths before we part. Knock within. Anon, anon, presently, presently.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But Tony, Tony, Tony, let it alone, for tis Hawking time; My Hawk has been empty pannel'd these three houres.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I come, I come, presently, presently.
Hang Hawks, we'll have one pint.
By and by, By and by, I come I come.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Prethee Tony be nimble then.

Now had I as liefe goe a hanging as a hawking— Whatsoere the matter is, I ha'no mind to that sport. Ide rather ha' Cis in my armes, then a leash a Partridges in my poutch: Tis a feat Girle. O that this were my marriage day! on that condition I went barefoot to bed. Pretty Rogue! Well, I'm resolv'd, what ere come on't, I will marry and I must marry, and I will marry ere two dayes come to an end. Let my Lady get her a new Fawlconer, or eate Mutton if she please. O Mutton, Mutton, Mutton! Well, I must marry, and I will marry; To day I receive my wages, and to morrow Ile buy a Licence, and next day Cis and Ile clap hands, And hey! then up goe we.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here Frank, a Health to Cis.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Come, Ile pledge't, wer't a mile to the bottome. Pledges. Now Tony, fill me a cup: A Health to Madge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come away: Madge shall never go unpledg'd whilst I am worth a Pint, nor never want while I am worth a penny.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thou art grown wondrous kind to day, Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I think the Moone's i'th Hotti-totty, and all the loving Planicles are in Conjunction. Sirrah, I am so strangely taken within these two houres, that I ha'much adoe to keep my selfe honest.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hudds Wookers, I'm i'th' same Predicature Tony. My Stars lend me honesty enough to light me to bed, and keep Cis out of my way. But tell me, how likest thou Cis?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Hougely well I perrest. As I live, tis a dainty Girle: She speaks so wisely and her words are so well
plac'd, and she lisps so prettily, and so thweetely, And sirrah they say that lithping wenches are good to kith. Now tell me thy opinion of Madge.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I tell thee Tony, she's as good a creature as ever liv'd in a house, and as well belov'd of the servants. Thou shalt have a dainty huswife, and an excellent Starcher, and one that my Master respects above all the rest. If his Band be to be pinn'd, no body can please him but Madge; When his Cornes are to be cut, none must do't but Madge. If his Cuffe-strings are to be ty'd, none can tye 'em but Madge. When his Muskadine and Egges are to be prepar'd, none can please him but Madge: When his head akes, Madge must hold it: If his back itch, Madge must scratch it: And to her credit be it spoken, he sweares, for a Foot, and a Leg, and a dainty black eye, and a white smoothe skin, and a—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No more good Frank, thou mak'st me mad. My Stars lend me but honesty enough till I have opportunity to lose it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And me but patience till Thursday.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Thursday?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If I breathe, Cis and Ile have a marriage day ont.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Say'st thou me so? Art in carnest? Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I, as sure as this is flesh, and blood, & knuckles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If Madge and I don't the like (if she be as willing as I) hang Tony. But shall's marry in our old Cloathes?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Huds diggers, I'de not stay till Friday for the Kings Wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
A match then! Give me thy clutch, Bring them bither a Thursday morning, by break a day, and wee'l
dispatch the businesse before the Crow pisse. Now Frank, here's a Health to the happy day.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Let it come, boy.
Here's another to the happy night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come away.
Anon, anon, presently, presently.
Farewell Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Tony farewell, and remember—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Very very welcome, Gentlemen.
A pint a Canary in the Lyon, Skore!

div.stage: Evald. Museus, Artesio, Form: Com: Kettreena, Rosia, Marina, Officers.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: I cannot rest, Artesio, till I purge
This groaning Land of Pertenax his blood.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: See, here the Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.l: Mercy, O mercy, gracious Prince.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Mercy, dread Soveraigne, mercy.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Wretches; The way to Mercy, is Confession.
Speak truth, Are ye guilty of this murther?

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.l: Most gracious Prince, I was no Actor in it.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: Nor I Contriver, may it please your grace.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: No, She contrived, and He acted it.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Speak, is it so? Come speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.p: True gracious Soveraigne, but we hope for mercy from your gracious hands.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Say, what Confederates had ye?

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.l: May't please your Grace, Lactusia set me on.

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.l: Trippit first call'd me in.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: She has her punishment: Who writ the Letter?

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.l: The Queene, most Royall Sir.

sp.speaker: Quack.
sp.p: Who promis'd on her Royall faith to stand 'twixt me and danger. Sir, for her deare sake be gracious,

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: O marble hearts, to plot so vile a fact
Against such Dove-like Innocence as this.

div.l: Well, take them hence, and see due Justice done
According to our Lawes, whereof we charge
A present Execution.

sp.speaker: Prisoners.
sp.l: Mercy, O Mercy. Tis the first offence.
Be gracious to us. Mercy, mercy.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Officers, Away with them.

div.l: Since Heaven hath pleased to deprive us thus
Of our deare Consort, our beloved Queene,
We think it fit, to let our people know
That we have made a second choice, to cafe
The weighty Burthen of our carefull Crowne.
Kettreena, bring the Crowne.
And for thy paines,
We here accept thee for our lawfull Spouse,
To be our Consort in Augusta's stead:
In pledge whereof we crowne thy Royall head.
Dost thou consent Kettreena?

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.p: Be pleas'd most Royall Sir to Give me leave to disburthen my conscience of a secret that concernes the State.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Speak on.

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.l: Sir, Augusta was no lawfull Queene.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: The woman's mad.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Away with her.

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.l: Good Sir be pleas'd to heare me out.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Speak on, speak on.

sp.speaker: Lact.
sp.p: Kettreena was the lawfull Queene, whom newly borne, I then her Nurse, exchang'd for Augusta your late wife, who was no other but Artesio's daughter.

div.l: Entic'd by him I did it, unto which
He did corrupt me with a great reward.
That this is truth, I seale it with my blood.
Artesio, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Artesio speak. What say'st to this?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Sir I'm a dying man, if not by Law, by age.
I, whom my frozen blood denyes to blush,
Must not be bold to lye.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I'm likely to have a fine pull of this.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Lactusia speaks but truth: The Act's confest.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Are my hopes come to this?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: My life or death lies in Kettreena's brest.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Officers conduct the Pris'ners back, and stay
Their execution till you farther heare:
If this be so, Evaldus must resigne
Both place and Crowne,
And now an humble Subject joyne

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: With all the rest, and say, LONG LIVE OUR QUEENE KETTREENA.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: And now Museus may goe hang himselfe.

sp.speaker: Kett.
sp.l: Being thus ordain'd by heavenly powers to wear
The facred Crowne of unexpected Care;
And well advising, what great danger waits
Upon the Scepters of ungovern'd States:
Conscious of too much weaknesse to command
So great a Kingdome with a single hand:
W'are pleas'd to choose a Consort, in whose care
The Realme hath prosper'd, and to whom we dare
Commit our selfe and it.
Evaldus, to requite thy charge, we choose
Thee our deare Husband, and with sacred vowes
We make thee partner in our unknowne bed,
And set this Crowne Imperiall on thy head.
And let the tongues of our good Subjects ring
Loud peales of joy,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: LONG LIVE EVALDUS KING.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: Two Crowns have blest Evaldus in one houre.
This crowns my heart with joy:

div.l: This crowns my head with power.
Faire Queene, Artesio's punishment we leave
To thy dispose.

sp.speaker: Kett.
sp.l: The personall offence we freely pardon;
But for the publique wrong, we must confine him.

sp.speaker: Evald.
sp.l: And left that after-Ages
Should interrupt the right of true succession,
We charge Museus to the self-same place:
Where they shall want for nothing, but enjoy
(Excepting Freedome) their owne hearts desires.
Meane while, what Art, and Industry can doe
T'expresse our joyes, and Subjects full content,
Let not be wanting: Let us bend our care
T'advance a publique mirth, and to prepare
Such Triumphs, whose bright Honour might display
A panick joy, and glorifie the day
Of Marriage-Royall, solemniz'd betweene
New-crown'd Evaldus, and his Royall Queene.
